title: Policies and Goals
historical_context: This article reflects the mindset of the 29A group, a collective known for their virus coding and hacker culture during the late 1990s. It provides insight into the ethical considerations and motivations behind their activities.
target_audience: Hackers, virus developers, security researchers, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: The article outlines the 29A group's stance on virus creation, emphasizing their focus on coding for fun and learning rather than malicious intent. It discusses their goals and the challenges they face in maintaining a responsible approach to virus development.
summary:
In 'Policies and Goals', the 29A group articulates their philosophy regarding the creation and dissemination of computer viruses. They clarify that while they do not endorse destructive payloads, they do not prohibit their members from including such features in their work. The group acknowledges the legal repercussions that can arise from virus creation, citing examples like The Black Baron, yet they maintain that their primary motivation is the enjoyment and intellectual challenge of coding. They view virus development as a hobby, aimed at exploring new techniques and improving existing ones across various operating systems.

The article also touches on the group's commitment to producing unique and interesting viruses, alongside their goal of releasing their magazine more frequently. They emphasize the importance of beta-testing their work, although they admit that bugs may still exist. Importantly, the 29A group distances itself from responsibility for the actions of its members, highlighting the individual nature of their pursuits. This piece serves as a fascinating glimpse into the mindset of a hacker collective during a time when virus coding was both a technical challenge and a form of self-expression.
